column1: #Text=# UniHD at TSAR-2022 Shared Task: Is Compute All We Need for Lexical Simplification?
#Text=This repository contains the modifications made by our team for the (winning) entry in the English shared task category.
#Text=We further include modifications made for Spanish and Portuguese, obtaining SotA in those languages as well.
#Text=**Find the arXiv version of our paper here: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01764**
#Text=In case you find these results useful, please consider citing our work in addition to the shared task paper (see below).
#Text=title = {{UniHD at TSAR-2022 Shared Task: Is Compute All We Need for Lexical Simplification?}}
#Text=To run the results for the respective subsets, you need to provide your own OpenAI API key in a file named `config.py`.
#Text=A template can be found in `config.py.template`, which already contains the correct variable name and structure.
#Text=Other required packages can be installed with `python3 -m pip install -r requirements.txt` from the main repository folder.

#Text=Obtaining predictions from the API should be possible by running `context_predictor.py` for English results, and the `_es.py` and `\\_pt.py` files for Spanish and Portuguese predictions, respectively.
#Text=Our predictions submitted to the workshop can be found either in the subfolder `en/`, or the fiel `UniHD.zip`.
#Text=Later additions of the Spanish and Portuguese predictions are in the respective folders `es/` (for Spanish) and `pt/` (Portuguese).

#Text=An exact reproduction of the system outputs may not be possible, as the generation temperature and other, server-side factors, such as the random seed, can potentially lead to differing predictions.
#Text=In our experience, there is no possibility of fixing a particular prediction to occur with 100% likelihood.
#Text=We also do not make any promises that the used prompt templates work with later models.
#Text=In our experiments, we used the (relatively "outdated" `text-davinci-002` model, which may respond differently to prompt variants than later additions
#Text=# Original README: TSAR-2022-Shared-Task Datasets and Evaluation Scripts
#Text=TSAR2022 Shared Task on Lexical Simplification for English (en), Spanish (es) and Portuguese (pt) - Datasets and Evaluation scripts
#Text=Please look at the website of the Shared Task for more details about the Evaluation Benchmark, Guidelines, Registration Form, etc...
#Text=There is no training dataset for the TSAR-2022 Shared Task.
#Text=However, a sample of 10 or 12 instances with gold standard annotations is provided here as a trial/sample dataset.
#Text=The trial dataset consists of a set of 10 instances (for English and Portuguese) and 12 instances (for Spanish) of a sentence, a target complex word.
#Text=The *trial_none* files contain only the instances and the *trial_gold* files contain the instances and set of gold annotations
#Text=The *test_none* files (used for the evaluation benchmark) contain the instances with the sentences and target complex words
#Text=The *test_gold* files contain the sentences, target complex words, and gold annotations
#Text=The official results for each language (en, es, and pt) can be found in this directory:

#Text=Evaluation Script for the TSAR-2022 Lexical Simplification Shared Task
#Text=  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
#Text=  --gold_file=<PATH>    The path to the file with the gold annotated instances
#Text=                        The path to file with the predictions
#Text=A paper describing the compilation of the datasets for English, Portuguese and Spanish that includes several experiments with
#Text=two state-of-the-art approaches for Lexical Simplification has been published at this link:
#Text=[Lexical Simplification Benchmarks for English, Portuguese, and Spanish](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/frai.2022.991242).
#Text=Sanja Štajner, Daniel Ferrés, Matthew Shardlow, Kai North, Marcos Zampieri and  Horacio Saggion.
